notes: [^1] Some implementations of ECDSA and DSA incorrectly encode r and s by not including leading zeros in the ASN encoding of integers when necessary. Hence, some implementations (e.g. jdk) allow signatures with incorrect ASN encodings assuming that the signature is otherwise valid.
[^2] Edge case values such as r=1 and s=0 can lead to forgeries if the ECDSA implementation does not check boundaries and computes s^(-1)==0.
[^3] Some implementations of ECDSA do not handle duplication and points at infinity correctly. This is a test vector that has been specially crafted to check for such an omission.
